Leading up to tonight's Class of 2020 virtual graduation, we want you to meet the man behind the mic! Carl Pfeiffer has been Arlington High's commencement name reader since the second graduating class in 2009.

Learning how to pronounce roughly 500 names each year is no easy feat, so he typically begins practicing the pronunciations in March by calling students down to his classroom. Since school was out much of the semester, he made phone calls instead to ensure he pronounced their names correctly during the special diploma walk. It's one part of graduation we often tend to forget about, but we thank Mr. Pfeiffer for his dedication to "getting it right."

Make sure to tune in tonight at 7 p.m. to celebrate our graduates! You can watch here on the ACS Facebook page, the AHS Tigerlife YouTube page or on Comcast Channel 152 if you live in Arlington. #ArlingtonGrad2020 #ACSproud #ArlingtonSchools

Arlington Middle School brought back a familiar face to speak at this month's Character Counts program! Jonathan Bowlan, who attended ACS until his senior year, was drafted by the Kansas City Royals in 2018 to play for its Minor League team in Idaho. He has since worked his way up to the High A division, now playing for the Wilmington Blue Rocks in Deleware.

Jonathan spoke to the students about the values of dedication, teamwork, commitment, and surrounding yourself with positive influences. He even signed a few autographs after his speech.

"I just wanted them to know that all you have to do is push yourself to reach your goals," Bowlan said. "Dreams can become a reality. I just hope they stay dedicated, chase those dreams and don't let anything stop them." #ACSproud #ArlingtonSchools

There's nothing like having ACS alumni come back to speak to our students! A special thanks to Marissa Green (Class of 2018) for speaking to the AHS PAVE Academy and AP Art students today. Marissa currently attends the Cinema Makeup School in Los Angeles where she studies special-effects makeup.

She's had the opportunity to create everything from sculptured monsters and prosthetics to digital animations. She's also practicing movie set and stage makeup while learning from Hollywood movie experts.

"Marissa really showed our students that you don't have to be 'just an artist,'" AHS teacher Melanie Anderson said. "You can take what you've learned here and travel down many different paths and create yourself a wonderful, fulfilling and off-the-beaten-path career." #ACSproud #ArlingtonSchools #PAVE #art

Laura Potts is a passionate school psychologist who has been with ACS for the past three years. She comes from a long-line of educators and decided to mix her love of psychology with her family history.

"One of the earliest cases in my career involved a student with extremely poor vision, some other disabilities and a low socioeconomic background. One day, I needed to test her but she didn't have her glasses. My principal and I got into the car and drove to the little girl's apartment to get her glasses so I could assess her. I remember how we tried our best to make this child's life better.

I often think about this family and how much it meant to them that we cared so much and that we went out of the way to get her the services she desperately needed in the school system. I hold that little girl's story close to my heart." #ACSproud #ArlingtonSchools #NationalSchoolPsychologistWeek

We're celebrating National School Psychologist Appreciation Week by introducing you to two of our wonderful psychologists!

First up - Susan Knight has been with ACS since we first opened, but she has a long career in school psychology. She works directly with children and parents to ensure they're succeeding academically, socially, behaviorally and emotionally.

"I have a brother with dyslexia, and I always saw how he struggled in school. I went down this career path because I knew it would be a good way for me to help students, ones just like my brother, be successful.

In some cases, we're identifying disabilities that the parent has never had someone tell them. It may not be the news they want to hear, but it's a starting point to help their child be more successful going forward. We're giving voice to a concern that may have been there all along, so it's rewarding to help guide families to something greater." #ACSproud #ArlingtonSchools

Sometimes, the best learning happens by bringing in outside guests to speak about their own experiences in life and career, and the AHS Art Department is great about this!

Recently, thanks to a grant from The RiverArtsFest, local artist Maysey Craddock spoke to the #PAVEAcademy and students about her journey as an artist. Craddock is best known for her visceral gouache paintings, which are typically painted onto brown paper bags.

"Having my artwork in front of young people and students is exciting because they're in a completely different place in their lives, and the possibilities are endless," Craddock said. "To see them latching onto different paths and different ways of being a person in this world is really exciting." #TeachArlington #ArlingtonSchools #ACSproud
